questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents with a history of low grade fever since the last two weeks. He has generalised lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Serum calcium was 13.2mg/dl. The peripheral smear is shown below. Flow cytometry revealed cells to be CD4+ CD25 and CD2+ CD3+ CD5+ but negative for CD7. What is your diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adult T cell leukemia/lymphoma The pathognomonic finding Of adult T-cell leukemia is the malignant “flower cell” that is positive for CD4 and CD25, as well as CD2, CD3, and CD5 but lacking The peripheral blood smear shows a typical “flower-shaped ” nucleus of adult T cell leukemia/lymphoma(ATLL). ATLL is a neoplasm driven by HTLV-1, Often contracted through the breast milk of infected mothers. There are 4 common variants- acute(60%),lymphomatous(20%),chronic(15%) and smoldering(5%) . Most common presentations include hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, hypercalcemia, lytic bone lesions and opportunistic infections. Combination chemotherapy is generally used. Other active agents in this disease include the antiretroviral agent zidovudine, interferon α, and arsenic. In non-responders to therapy, allogeneic stem cell transplants should be considered.

Hairy cell leukemia is a tumor of small lymphocytes with oval nuclei, abundant cytoplasm, and distinctive membrane projections (hairy cells). Clinical features:- The male-to-female ratio is 5:1, and the median age is 50. Most patients present with gradual onset of fatigue, symptoms related to a markedly enlarged spleen, and some symptoms of infection. Massive splenomegaly .liver is enlarged in 50% of cases.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male who has recurrent respiratory tract infections and a history of fatigue came to the hospital and had a routine blood checkup done. On his results, the doctor found out that the patient had anemia and pancytopenia, mainly neutropenia. On examination , the patient has massive splenomegaly with mild hepatomegaly, whereas no lymph nodes are involved. Bone marrow aspirate was found to be a dry tap. Immunotyping by Flow cytometry for CD103, CD22, and CD11c.What is the clinical diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hairy cell leukemia All the given options are unusual lymphoid malignancies Based on the clinical picture and features of dry tap , the correct option is {a}

Highyeild:

Hairy cells strongly express pan-B cell antigens including CD19, CD20 , and CD22, and usually lack expression of CD5, CD10, CD21, CD23, and CD27 Hairy cells also characteristically express CD11c, CD25, CD103, CD123 (bright), and cyclin D1 (usually weak) A majority (74 per cent) of HCL also expresses annexin A1 , which is not defined in any other B cell neoplasm. The mucosal lymphocyte antigen, CD103, is a sensitive marker for HCL CD103, when co-expressed with other pan-B cell markers, is highly suggestive of HCL.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male had a bone marrow biopsy done, and it was a ‘dry tap’. What might be the possible diagnosis of this patient? He had a history of fatigue with lab values showing Hb: 8g%, platelets: 76,800 L/ml, along with neutropenia with massive splenomegaly:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hairy Cell Leukemia All the conditions here are associated with a dry tap in bone marrow aspirate.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. These patients have anemia and thrombocytopenia associated with leukocytosis and hence excluded Option: C. Splenic enlargement, anemia is seen, but the platelets and leukocyte counts are either normal or increased Option: D . Is excluded, as peripheral blood changes might have some effect on marrow, and it cannot be a normal one

Extraedge:

Differential Diagnosis of "Dry Tap"--Inability to Aspirate Bone Marrow Dry taps occur in about 4% of attempts and are associated with the following: Metastatic carcinoma infiltration 17% Chronic myeloid leukemia 15% Myelofibrosis 14% Hairy cell leukemia 10% Acute leukemia 10% Lymphomas, Hodgkin's disease 9% Normal marrow Rare

questions.text: A pathological report of a 51-year-old male shows tumors of small lymphocytes with oval nuclei, abundant cytoplasm, and distinctive membrane projections, with tumor markers having a strong expression of CD22, CD25, and CD103. Though the patient is started on chemotherapy, splenectomy is also given as a choice to the patient for prolonged remission of the disease. What is the condition we are dealing with?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hairy Cell Leukemia The given patient details with age and sex and tumor markers correlate to hairy cell Leukemia. The drug of choice initially is a nucleoside analogue in these patients, but there is a very high risk of immunosuppression on taking these drugs.
